summary: Jamie Lannister as one of the heroes from A Song about Jon and Sansa
title: Jamie Lannister as one of the heroes from A Song about Jon and Sansa
body:
As I mentioned here, D&D (and GRRM) have been hinting at a possible Stark-Lannister Coalition to stand together against the two elemental dangers of “Ice” (NK and his army of the dead) and “Fire” (Daenerys, her dragons, Dothraki horde and the Unsullied) for a while now. Of the Lannisters, I think, Jamie is most likely going to be the one to survive and end up playing a huge role not only during the Great War but also in the post-war rehabilitation of Westeros, perhaps as Hand to King Aegon/Jon of Houses Stark and Targaryen.

There seems to be a plethora of show evidence for Jamie as Hand of the King that @julibf  gathered here.

@fedonciadale talked about pieces of evidence from the books that could potentially foreshadow the same here.

Jamie served as the Lord Commander of the Kingsguard during both Joffrey’s and Tommen’s reign. The Kingsguards have a famous book called the Book of Brothers that chronicles all the heroic deeds of the great Kingsguards. 

In S4E01 Two Swords, Joffrey mocks Jamie about his lack of heroic deeds when they are in the Tower of the Kingsguard room discussing Kingsguard duty for Joffrey’s wedding with Margaery that takes place in the next episode.

Joffrey: Ser Jamie Lannister. Someone forgot to write down all your great deeds.

Jamie: There’s still time.

Joffrey: Is there? For a 40-year-old knight with one hand. How can you protect me with that?

Jamie: I use my left hand now, Your Grace. Makes for more of a contest.

Joffrey dies in the next episode and Jamie is unable to protect him when he dies of the poisoning.

<donning my tinfoil hat…>

Since Jon and Joffrey are foils of each other, I would like to believe that in S8, when Jon and the rest will be fighting the Night King, Jamie and his left hand will come in handy in successfully protecting Jon, the rightful King. Where Jamie failed in protecting Joffrey, he will succeed in protecting Jon. My personal headcanon is Jon and NK will duel but it will be Jamie who will end up killing the Night King, making it “more of a contest” with his left hand and thereby earning the name of Kingslayer again but this time, the realm and generations to come will sing songs about Jamie the Night Kingslayer with pride and adoration. Jamie will be hailed as one of the greatest knights the realm has ever seen. 

Something else also happened in Season 4 that makes me believe Jamie will be revered and “songs about his heroic deeds” will be sung in Westeros for years to come mainly because of the following scenes in S4E04 Oathkeeper.

The scene above is when Brienne and Jamie talk about finding Sansa Stark and Jamie gives Brienne, the Valyrian steel sword Oathkeeper. 

Brienne: Ser Jamie Lannister. Knighted and named the Kingsguard in his sixteenth year. At the sack of King’s Landing, murdered his King, Aerys the second. Pardoned by Robert Baratheon…..thereafter known as the Kingslayer.

Jamie: It’s the duty of the Lord Commander to fill those pages. And there’s still room left in mine.

As Jamie says the last line, the camera shows him turning to face Oathkeeper.

Jamie gives Brienne Oathkeeper and says “it was reforged from Ned Stark’s sword and you will use it to defend Ned Stark’s daughter”.

Jamie provides Brienne with newly made armour, a Valyrian steel sword Oathkeeper and Podrick Payne to send her off in a quest to find Sansa Stark and protect her.

This is heroic because in the same episode, S4E04, we have Cersei asking Jamie to find that “murderous little bitch” Sansa Stark and bring her head back to KL.

 Instead of heeding to his lover and sister, Cersei’s wishes, Jamie defies her orders and sends Brienne off to find Sansa.

In S6, we actually get to see Brienne and Podrick, rescuing Sansa from Ramsay’s men and hounds and take her safely back to Castle Black to reunite with Jon. Brienne then becomes Sansa’s sword shield (much like Jonquil Darke was to the Good Queen Alysanne in Fire and Blood).

I like to think that years down the line, one of the first things that will be sung about Ser Jamie Lannister will be his defiance of Cersei’s orders, giving Brienne, Oathkeeper, forged from Ned Stark’s Ice to protect Ned Stark’s daughter, who became the greatest Queen of Westeros. (I am positive we will see Sansa becoming The Queen in S8)

In the songs about Jon and Sansa, Ser Jamie Lannister’s name will be sung for his heroic deed in helping find and protect Sansa Stark and also hopefully Jon in S8.

One of Jamie’s heroic deeds is happening as he speaks about “there’s still room in mine” and we don’t even realize it until later, after the conclusion of the story, when Sansa will actually become Queen.

Jamie and Brienne’s interaction in Season 4 is modeled around Jamie and Ser Loras Tyrell’s interaction in Jamie II AFFC from the books. And it is this interaction that further foreshadows that Jamie will be remembered in songs.

We have Jamie II in AFFC, where he is sitting in the common room of the White Sword Tower, with a cup of Dornish red and the White Book.

He was turning pages with the stump of his sword hand when the Knight of Flowers entered, removed his cloak and swordbelt and hung them on a wall peg next to Jaime’s.

The Knight of Flowers, Ser Loras Tyrell, who is a Jon stand-in, and Jamie converse about the various Kingsguards who have achieved various feats in their lifetimes and their great deeds have been inscribed in the pages of the White Book (Book of Brothers in the show).

“Most deserved to be forgotten. The heroes will always be remembered. The best.

“The best and the worst”. So one of us is like to live in song. “And a few who were a bit of both. Like him.” He tapped the page he had been reading.

“Who?” Ser Loras craned his head around to see. “Ten black pellets on a scarlet field. I do not know those arms.”

“They belonged to Criston Cole, who served the first Viserys and the second Aegon.” Jaime closed the White Book.

“They called him Kingmaker”.

-Jamie II, AFFC

Ser Loras Tyrell is dead on the show and gravely injured, the last time we hear of him in the books. So “one of us is like to live in song” most likely indicates Jamie Lannister here, who gets to live in “A Song of Ice and Fire” or as I like to call it “A Song of Jon and Sansa”.

What’s really interesting about this particular conversation is the talk about Ser Criston Cole. 

There are 3 times in all the books that his name pops up, twice in A Soiled Knight and once in Jamie II in AFFC.

Ser Criston Cole was Lord Commander of the Kingsguard during King Viserys I Targaryen’s rule and was thought to be instrumental in bringing about the first Dance of the Dragons by supporting Aegon II’s cause by going against his alleged lover, Queen Rhaenyra. 

The following is a conversation between Ser Arys Oakheart, who accompanies Myrcella to Dorne and Arianne Martell, when they are plotting to put Myrcella on the Iron Throne by usurping Tommen.

“The first Viserys intended his daughter Rhaenyra to follow him, do you deny it? But as the king lay dying the Lord Commander of his Kingsguard decided that it should be otherwise.

”Ser Criston Cole. Criston the Kingmaker had set brother against sister and divided the Kingsguard against itself, bringing on the terrible war the singers named the Dance of the Dragons. Some claimed he acted from ambition, for Prince Aegon was more tractable than his willful older sister. Others allowed him nobler motives, and argued that he was defending ancient Andal custom. A few whispered that Ser Criston had been Princess Rhaenyra’s lover before he took the white and wanted vengeance on the woman who had spurned him. “The Kingmaker wrought grave harm,” Ser Arys said, “and gravely did he pay for it, but …”

“… but perhaps the Seven sent you here so that one white knight might make right what another set awry. You do know that when my father returns to the Water Gardens he plans to take Myrcella with him?”

-The Soiled Knight, AFFC

I think Ser Criston Cole is foreshadowing for Jamie. Jamie is the Soiled Knight, infamous as the Kingslayer for killing the Mad King Aerys, and will play a part in the second Dance with Dragons when he chooses the North (I pledged to ride North and I intend to honor that pledge from S7E07) and the Starks (Sansa Stark is my last chance at honor, ASOS). Ser Criston Cole choosing Aegon II over Queen Rhaenyra in a way mirrors Jamie choosing the Starks over Cersei. 

(Queen Rhaenyra vs Aegon II, of course, also mirrors Daenerys vs Jon in Dance of the Dragons 2.0 that is incoming in S8) 

Like Ser Criston Cole, who was a bit of both best and worst, Jamie started the story as the Kingslayer, pushed Bran out of the window, but has slowly made a turnaround after he lost his sword hand, following his capture by Robb Stark. In the books and show (S6), he has been striving to maintain peace in the Riverlands. In the show we saw, Jamie trying to take out Daenerys, in a suicidal attempt, to prevent further destruction and loss of lives of the Lannister Army during the Field of Fire 2.0. 

The conversation between Jamie Lannister and Ser Loras Tyrell, in Jamie II AFFC, ends with talk about Ser Criston Cole being the Kingmaker. I think this foreshadows Jamie being the Kingmaker and also the Queenmaker. The chapter that immediately follows Jamie II is Cersei IV, where Cersei remembers Maggy the Frog and her prophecy about the YMBQ coming to cast her down and take all that she holds dear. 

How ironic will it be that Jamie, Cersei’s brother and lover, is the one instrumental in saving and protecting Sansa Stark who ends up becoming the prophesied YMBQ to cast Cersei down? And in pure GRRM fashion, I think, that feat in and of itself deserves to be sung about. Jamie gets to end the story as a hero.

One thing is for sure, whoever Jamie Lannister supports will have a strong case to win the throne. He not only is a great fighter but has powers of persuasion to draw the most recalcitrant Lords into his own fold (think Edmure Tully, Randyll Tarly).

Another thing that subtly foreshadowed Jamie becoming the Kingmaker and perhaps Hand of the King was this official cover image of GOT Season 2. This is major tinfoil but I think there might be something to it.

Season 2 was about War of the Five Kings, five factions clamouring for the Iron Throne…but look closer.

That’s a left hand holding the crown of the King of the Seven Kingdoms.

A LEFT HAND!!!!

And we all know what happened in the following season (Season 3), right?

Jamie Lannister loses his right hand in Episode 3 Walk of Punishment.

Also, I would really like Jamie Lannister to survive the series and become Lord of Casterly Rock, marry Brienne and father a brood of golden-haired babies.

I am tagging @julibf  @silentbutsweet77 @fedonciadale since they seem to be positively inclined to Jamie as the Hand theory.

In the books and show (S6), he has been striving to maintain peace in the Riverlands. In the show we saw, Jamie trying to take out Daenerys, in a suicidal attempt, to prevent further destruction and loss of lives of the Lannister Army during the Field of Fire 2.0. 

The conversation between Jamie Lannister and Ser Loras Tyrell, in Jamie II AFFC, ends with talk about Ser Criston Cole being the Kingmaker. I think this foreshadows Jamie being the Kingmaker and also the Queenmaker. The chapter that immediately follows Jamie II is Cersei IV, where Cersei remembers Maggy the Frog and her prophecy about the YMBQ coming to cast her down and take all that she holds dear. 

How ironic will it be that Jamie, Cersei’s brother and lover, is the one instrumental in saving and protecting Sansa Stark who ends up becoming the prophesied YMBQ to cast Cersei down? And in pure GRRM fashion, I think, that feat in and of itself deserves to be sung about. Jamie gets to end the story as a hero.

One thing is for sure, whoever Jamie Lannister supports will have a strong case to win the throne. He not only is a great fighter but has powers of persuasion to draw the most recalcitrant Lords into his own fold (think Edmure Tully, Randyll Tarly).

Another thing that subtly foreshadowed Jamie becoming the Kingmaker and perhaps Hand of the King was this official cover image of GOT Season 2. This is major tinfoil but I think there might be something to it.

Season 2 was about War of the Five Kings, five factions clamouring for the Iron Throne…but look closer.

That’s a left hand holding the crown of the King of the Seven Kingdoms.

A LEFT HAND!!!!

And we all know what happened in the following season (Season 3), right?

Jamie Lannister loses his right hand in Episode 3 Walk of Punishment.

Also, I would really like Jamie Lannister to survive the series and become Lord of Casterly Rock, marry Brienne and father a brood of golden-haired babies.

I am tagging @julibf  @silentbutsweet77 @fedonciadale since they seem to be positively inclined to Jamie as the Hand theory.
trail.content:
As I mentioned here, D&D (and GRRM) have been hinting at a possible Stark-Lannister Coalition to stand together against the two elemental dangers of “Ice” (NK and his army of the dead) and “Fire” (Daenerys, her dragons, Dothraki horde and the Unsullied) for a while now. Of the Lannisters, I think, Jamie is most likely going to be the one to survive and end up playing a huge role not only during the Great War but also in the post-war rehabilitation of Westeros, perhaps as Hand to King Aegon/Jon of Houses Stark and Targaryen.

There seems to be a plethora of show evidence for Jamie as Hand of the King that @julibf  gathered here.

@fedonciadale talked about pieces of evidence from the books that could potentially foreshadow the same here.

Jamie served as the Lord Commander of the Kingsguard during both Joffrey’s and Tommen’s reign. The Kingsguards have a famous book called the Book of Brothers that chronicles all the heroic deeds of the great Kingsguards. 

In S4E01 Two Swords, Joffrey mocks Jamie about his lack of heroic deeds when they are in the Tower of the Kingsguard room discussing Kingsguard duty for Joffrey’s wedding with Margaery that takes place in the next episode.

Joffrey: Ser Jamie Lannister. Someone forgot to write down all your great deeds.

Jamie: There’s still time.

Joffrey: Is there? For a 40-year-old knight with one hand. How can you protect me with that?

Jamie: I use my left hand now, Your Grace. Makes for more of a contest.

Joffrey dies in the next episode and Jamie is unable to protect him when he dies of the poisoning.

<donning my tinfoil hat…>

Since Jon and Joffrey are foils of each other, I would like to believe that in S8, when Jon and the rest will be fighting the Night King, Jamie and his left hand will come in handy in successfully protecting Jon, the rightful King. Where Jamie failed in protecting Joffrey, he will succeed in protecting Jon. My personal headcanon is Jon and NK will duel but it will be Jamie who will end up killing the Night King, making it “more of a contest” with his left hand and thereby earning the name of Kingslayer again but this time, the realm and generations to come will sing songs about Jamie the Night Kingslayer with pride and adoration. Jamie will be hailed as one of the greatest knights the realm has ever seen. 

Something else also happened in Season 4 that makes me believe Jamie will be revered and “songs about his heroic deeds” will be sung in Westeros for years to come mainly because of the following scenes in S4E04 Oathkeeper.

The scene above is when Brienne and Jamie talk about finding Sansa Stark and Jamie gives Brienne, the Valyrian steel sword Oathkeeper. 

Brienne: Ser Jamie Lannister. Knighted and named the Kingsguard in his sixteenth year. At the sack of King’s Landing, murdered his King, Aerys the second. Pardoned by Robert Baratheon…..thereafter known as the Kingslayer.

Jamie: It’s the duty of the Lord Commander to fill those pages. And there’s still room left in mine.

As Jamie says the last line, the camera shows him turning to face Oathkeeper.

Jamie gives Brienne Oathkeeper and says “it was reforged from Ned Stark’s sword and you will use it to defend Ned Stark’s daughter”.

Jamie provides Brienne with newly made armour, a Valyrian steel sword Oathkeeper and Podrick Payne to send her off in a quest to find Sansa Stark and protect her.

This is heroic because in the same episode, S4E04, we have Cersei asking Jamie to find that “murderous little bitch” Sansa Stark and bring her head back to KL.

 Instead of heeding to his lover and sister, Cersei’s wishes, Jamie defies her orders and sends Brienne off to find Sansa.

In S6, we actually get to see Brienne and Podrick, rescuing Sansa from Ramsay’s men and hounds and take her safely back to Castle Black to reunite with Jon. Brienne then becomes Sansa’s sword shield (much like Jonquil Darke was to the Good Queen Alysanne in Fire and Blood).

I like to think that years down the line, one of the first things that will be sung about Ser Jamie Lannister will be his defiance of Cersei’s orders, giving Brienne, Oathkeeper, forged from Ned Stark’s Ice to protect Ned Stark’s daughter, who became the greatest Queen of Westeros. (I am positive we will see Sansa becoming The Queen in S8)

In the songs about Jon and Sansa, Ser Jamie Lannister’s name will be sung for his heroic deed in helping find and protect Sansa Stark and also hopefully Jon in S8.

One of Jamie’s heroic deeds is happening as he speaks about “there’s still room in mine” and we don’t even realize it until later, after the conclusion of the story, when Sansa will actually become Queen.

Jamie and Brienne’s interaction in Season 4 is modeled around Jamie and Ser Loras Tyrell’s interaction in Jamie II AFFC from the books. And it is this interaction that further foreshadows that Jamie will be remembered in songs.

We have Jamie II in AFFC, where he is sitting in the common room of the White Sword Tower, with a cup of Dornish red and the White Book.

He was turning pages with the stump of his sword hand when the Knight of Flowers entered, removed his cloak and swordbelt and hung them on a wall peg next to Jaime’s.

The Knight of Flowers, Ser Loras Tyrell, who is a Jon stand-in, and Jamie converse about the various Kingsguards who have achieved various feats in their lifetimes and their great deeds have been inscribed in the pages of the White Book (Book of Brothers in the show).

“Most deserved to be forgotten. The heroes will always be remembered. The best.

“The best and the worst”. So one of us is like to live in song. “And a few who were a bit of both. Like him.” He tapped the page he had been reading.

“Who?” Ser Loras craned his head around to see. “Ten black pellets on a scarlet field. I do not know those arms.”

“They belonged to Criston Cole, who served the first Viserys and the second Aegon.” Jaime closed the White Book.

“They called him Kingmaker”.

-Jamie II, AFFC

Ser Loras Tyrell is dead on the show and gravely injured, the last time we hear of him in the books. So “one of us is like to live in song” most likely indicates Jamie Lannister here, who gets to live in “A Song of Ice and Fire” or as I like to call it “A Song of Jon and Sansa”.

What’s really interesting about this particular conversation is the talk about Ser Criston Cole. 

There are 3 times in all the books that his name pops up, twice in A Soiled Knight and once in Jamie II in AFFC.

Ser Criston Cole was Lord Commander of the Kingsguard during King Viserys I Targaryen’s rule and was thought to be instrumental in bringing about the first Dance of the Dragons by supporting Aegon II’s cause by going against his alleged lover, Queen Rhaenyra. 

The following is a conversation between Ser Arys Oakheart, who accompanies Myrcella to Dorne and Arianne Martell, when they are plotting to put Myrcella on the Iron Throne by usurping Tommen.

“The first Viserys intended his daughter Rhaenyra to follow him, do you deny it? But as the king lay dying the Lord Commander of his Kingsguard decided that it should be otherwise.

”Ser Criston Cole. Criston the Kingmaker had set brother against sister and divided the Kingsguard against itself, bringing on the terrible war the singers named the Dance of the Dragons. Some claimed he acted from ambition, for Prince Aegon was more tractable than his willful older sister. Others allowed him nobler motives, and argued that he was defending ancient Andal custom. A few whispered that Ser Criston had been Princess Rhaenyra’s lover before he took the white and wanted vengeance on the woman who had spurned him. “The Kingmaker wrought grave harm,” Ser Arys said, “and gravely did he pay for it, but …”

“… but perhaps the Seven sent you here so that one white knight might make right what another set awry. You do know that when my father returns to the Water Gardens he plans to take Myrcella with him?”

-The Soiled Knight, AFFC

I think Ser Criston Cole is foreshadowing for Jamie. Jamie is the Soiled Knight, infamous as the Kingslayer for killing the Mad King Aerys, and will play a part in the second Dance with Dragons when he chooses the North (I pledged to ride North and I intend to honor that pledge from S7E07) and the Starks (Sansa Stark is my last chance at honor, ASOS). Ser Criston Cole choosing Aegon II over Queen Rhaenyra in a way mirrors Jamie choosing the Starks over Cersei. 

(Queen Rhaenyra vs Aegon II, of course, also mirrors Daenerys vs Jon in Dance of the Dragons 2.0 that is incoming in S8)

One thing is for sure, whoever Jamie Lannister supports will have a strong case to win the throne. He not only is a great fighter but has powers of persuasion to draw the most recalcitrant Lords into his own fold (think Edmure Tully, Randyll Tarly).

summary: "Reading this quote, it’s reasonable to assume that the actors replying to D&D first were excited and happy about what they did...
question: "Reading this quote, it’s reasonable to assume that the actors replying to D&D first were excited and happy about what they did with their character in the final season" - well it's not necessery with Sophie. She was rooting for dark Sansa for ages. And her dream was cool death scene.
answer:
I suppose anything is possible, anon, but I sincerely doubt we’re getting dark!sansa in s8. Unless one by dark!Sansa means a Sansa who’ll do everything in her power to protect her family, that is, because that’s exactly what she’ll do.

Since season one, the Starks have gone through one traumatic ordeal after another. They’ve been drowning in misery, fought tooth and nail to stay afloat, and the past few seasons, they’ve finally started making their way back to shore. S8 will be the season of the Starks. They’ll be together, work as a pack, and protect one another. And because they’ll use everything they’ve learned during these long, hard years apart, they’ll complement one another and form an incredibly strong team.

So Sansa–a young woman whose arc has set her on a path to rebuild, lead, and carry on the Stark name and legacy–is not very likely to die. That’s not how her story is going to end.

summary: I'm completely done with people criticizing Sansa for telling Dontos about her plans to marry Willas. At the end of the day, her...
body: I’m completely done with people criticizing Sansa for telling Dontos about her plans to marry Willas. At the end of the day, her wedding with him would have never happened. The Tyrells wanted to wait after Joffrey’s wedding to wed Sansa to Willas. But at the wedding, Joffrey would have died and Sansa would have most likely still try to escape (Dontos would have convinced her to) and she’ll still be on her way to the Vale. Her going to Dontos in the first place was only something a nice person would do. Let’s say someone planned this super awesome party for you but you know you can’t make it. Do you just not tell them you’re not going to make it and go somewhere else? No, you would tell them to cancel your party. Same with Sansa. It’s not about a big mouth, it’s about being a nice and considerate person. If she had a big mouth, people would have found out about her plans with Dontos long ago.

Mel: Well, it's not a Stark girl, and she came from the wrong side, but I was right on the whole.

description:
Christmas isn’t here yet but here’s a little something for you, if you’re reading this story :)

If you’ve ever had dinner at The Lion Gate, you’d know what it looks like: a white-tablecloth dining room with pretentious silverware, a lounge pianist hired precisely because he doesn’t give a shit about the diners’ indifference and a stuck-up, disdainful head waiter - the key element in any fancy restaurant.
Joffrey had chosen The Lion Gate to have dinner with Cersei and Sansa that night. I couldn’t quite identify the source of that barometric shift in the Lannister household but the fact was that Joffrey had decided to play ball and pretend he was having a blast with his mother and his girlfriend. He had told us to take the two women to the restaurant and that he was due to arrive later. From the nearby table where I was seated with Boros Blount, neither the blonde nor the redhead looked thrilled.

summary: Hello, I've been playing Persona for a while and it occured to me that Sansa Stark sounds like she could represent the Strength...
question: Hello, I've been playing Persona for a while and it occured to me that Sansa Stark sounds like she could represent the Strength Arcana. That card typically has a woman being calm and serene while in the presence of a lion. From what I understand the Strength Tarot Card is all about remaining gentle in the face of brute force. It's kind of surprising how that can fit with Sansa's storyline. I'm not sure if it's deliberate but I thought that it was a thought worth sharing. Thanks.
answer:
Hi. Why did you get flagged by Tumblr? I never saw anything explicit on your blog.

I’ve never played that game but that really does sound like Sansa. That’s her storyline in ASoS and ACoK.

title: It’s finally the day! Time to open presents!!
body:
I already have lots of the presents queued for later this day, so if you didn’t catch them in the tags make sure to check in with the blog to find them. And I will post the master list of all the fics in a couple days when I’m sure everyone that is going to post, posted. Here is a reminder on what you need to have to post your gift:

  • It must be tag correctly. The first two tags should be #SanSan Secret Santa and #Your Giftee’s Name. You can also add the @Name Here. So it’s more likely they will see it.  
  • If you are writing a fic then it must be a minimum of 1000 words, complete, and original.
  • You can post your gift on a different website but you must at least post a link to it on Tumblr so I can reblog it to the SanSanSecretSanta blog. And if Tumblr is being difficult and making it hard for you to post on your blog make sure to tell me and I will make a post on where your giftee can find their present.

title: fic: somebody to love (sandor/sansa), nc17, for sansan secret santa 2018
body:
AAAAND HELLO @amphipolitan the secret santa is not so secret anymore ;) I hope you enjoy this monster and apologies in advance for the dentist’s bill in case the fluff is beyond control X°D

somebody to love, sandor/sansa, sansa & all the other stark men, sansa & jeyne poole, minor/past sansa/joffrey; nc17/explicit sexual content (full tags/warnings on ao3), 22,5k ca, for @sansansecretsanta 2018 for the prompt the men in her life;

“Excuse me,” Robb says, “after that arse Joffrey maybe I wanted to be sure this wasn’t another very bad life choice.”

“Oh, for — Robb, that’s sweet, but he’s the guy who warned me to dump his ass, so maybe you could have, you know, called before showing up with the cavalry?”

At that, Robb looks mortified —

For one single second.

“Couldn’t you have just said?” He grins, and then she’s sure he doesn’t try to pat Sandor on the back or something because the body language is screaming don’t, but his entire attitude changes in a moment. “Man, did you really warn her off that prick?”

Or: where Sansa Stark’s first boyfriend turns out to be an extremely bad choice, but it eventually brings someone much, much better into her life.

summary: Random hopes and head canons for Arya and Sansa
title: Random hopes and head canons for Arya and Sansa
body:
- Sansa dressing Arya. Making a Arya a Catelyn-like collar or an embroidered cloak with a wolf. Arya needs to dress more like a Stark, damnit! It would be doubly interesting if Sansa finds some of Lyanna’s things and gives them to Arya.

- Sansa teaching Arya about the politics of the North, showing Arya the boring parts of ruling it. I’m not sure if Arya still has this romanticized notion of what being a Lord is, someone who fights in wars and has adventures, but it mostly involves management of your castle and lands. This would allow some of Arya’s protective instincts to shine through, maybe even recalling what Robb quoted from Ned about how everyone in the North is theirs to protect. Sansa is proud and happy to Arya’s support.

- Arya teaching Sansa some basic fighting skills. Jon did say that all of the boys and girls would need to learn how to fight. Sansa would not remove herself from that obligation. Maybe she tricks Arya a little? Arya hits Sansa during their lesson and Sansa pretends to be hurt worse than she is. Arya starts to apologize and Sansa pushes her down. Sansa makes a point to Arya about Cersei and how tricky and manipulative she is. How they can’t fight Cersei the same way they will fight the Night King and Cersei might be just as dangerous as he is.

My highest hope for next season is for Arya and Sansa to be there for each other. Listening to each other. Understanding each other. I don’t think we’ll get any hackneyed fight like last season but I hope they don’t let their relationship completely fall by the way side for more “important” things.

title:
Chapter 20 | Heggies Pizza
        |
        Minnesota, State Of...
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
“It wasn’t just Thanksgiving dear, it’s been everything,” Catelyn said heavily and when the kettle dinged, Sansa poured two mugs of tea. “Have I been a good mother to you?”

“Oh,” Sansa slid the mug across to her mother and sat down, surprised by the question. “I mean, yeah, mom. Yeah, of course.”

“It’s just that you were so easy,” Catelyn mused, “from the moment we brought you home, you never cried. Robb crawled into your crib once and was driving his trucks over you and you just laid there and watched him.”

“How nice of him,” Sansa remarked dryly.

“You were so easy, you always did exactly what I asked from you. And everyone else, for that matter. You were so eager to help everyone, I never had to give you a second thought. Robb and the boys, they were little devils and they dragged Arya into it. But you were my little angel.”

“Well,” Sansa muttered, biting back reproachful words that were bubbling up. She wanted to tell her mother that just because she was a quiet, easy child didn’t make Catelyn’s indifference any easier. That it was just as hard to be the perfect daughter as anything else. That she sometimes felt like she was screaming into a void behind the smiling mask of a pretty young woman.
